VOL. XX, NO. 21.

BRICKLEY RESIGNS POSITION
Coach of Last Year's Championship Eleven Asks to Be Relc ased from Contract, Due to Pressure of
Business Obligations.

It has been officially announced
that Charles E. Brickley will not
be Hopkins football coach again
next fall.
The Johns Hopkins Football
Committee had not announced, at
time of going to press, who would
succeed Brickley, but report has it
that "Hank" Brennick will be given
the position. Brickley will coach
Boston College next year.
The statement given out by the
Football Committee is as follows:
"Mr. Charles Brickley, of Harvard, who coached the Johns Hopkins University football team last
year, appeared before the Football
Committee of the University today
(March 13), and stated that subsequent to his signing of the contract
to coach at Hopkins next year he
had made business connections in
Boston, which an absence of three
months to coach at Johns Hopkins
would seriouSly jeopardize."
After a full talk with Mr. Brickley, the committee informed him
that .they would recommend, although with keen regret, that his
resignation be accepted by the Athletic Board of the University,• on
the grounds that they ,were unwilling that his • contract to coach
Johns Hopkins next year should
interfere with his permanant business prospects.
-Mr. Brickley informed the committee that he would probably do
some coaching at Harvard during
the coming fall, but that this would
be of such a nature that it would
not interfere with his business
plans.
The Football Committee is considering the appointment of Mr.
Brickley's successor, as well as an
assistant coach.
Y. M. C. A. TO ELECT OFFICERS
AT GENERAL MASS-MEETING

The annual election of officers of
the Young Men's Christian Association of this University will take
place sometime this week in the
chapel of Levering Hall. Contrary
to the usual custom, the officers
Nv ill be elected in a mass-meeting
of all the interested students.
This action is taken as part of
the campaign on the part of the Y.
M. C. A. to have the students feel
that the Association is one of their
own institutions, and that they have
an interest in its organization. A
large attendance is expected for this
meeting. which is by far the most
important of the year.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 27, 1916.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

MILITARY TRAINING BEGINS THIS WEEK
Drills to Take Place Both in Gymnasium and at Homewood Under
Direction of Mr. Kistler—Course Entirely Voluntary,
But in Future to Be Compulsory for
Freshmen and Sophomores.
This Monday witnessed the installation of military training at Johns
Hopkins University. It is just possible that unforeseen developments
may postpone the actual commencement of the course until next week;
but it is. almost assured that, by the time this issue reaches the hands of
its readers, military training will have already begun.
Until the special officer detailed by the War Department reaches here,
the men will be put under Mr. Theodore Kistler, the present gymnasium
instructor. The . first part of the training will consist in rudimentary
drills and setting-up exercises. It is probable that guns and uniforms
will be on hand before the end of the year. _
The men volunteering to take the course this spring will rest under
no legal obligation. Beginning next year, however, those taking the
full course provided by the Government for the establishment of a
Reserve Officers Corps will form part of the reserve of the United
States military forces.
1\1H:tory training will begin at
Johns Hopkins University this
Monday.
Definite announcement to this effect was made a few days ago by
Dean Brush. The requisite number of students have volunteered
to take the course this spring, the
War College has given its approval
to the movement, and all preparations are rapidly • being completed
for the installation of the course before .the next fortnight has elapsed.
The officer who is to be detailed
by the War Department to take
charge of the Hopkins corps has
not yet been appointed, and until
his arrival, the men will be put under the charge of the present gymnasium instructor, Mr. Theodore
Kistler. The first few weeks of
drill must inevitably be devoted to
practice in rudimentary formations
and to setting-up exercises, and
Mr. Kistler has amply demonstrated
his proficiency in instruction -along
these lines to o long succession of
freshman classes.
- It is planned to form two squads
of the men this spring, one to drill
in the cage, and the other, composed chiefly of the engineering
students, to drill at Homewood.
These arrangements are, of course,
only temporary. When the officer
appointed by the War Department
arrives, it. is expected that the men
will be far enough advanced to permit of the formation of the regular
student corps.
The drills will be held every
Monday, Wednesday and Friday
.afternoon at 5 o'clock.
Although participation in the
course will be entirely voluntary
this year, beginning nest fall, it will
be made compulsory for freshmen
a
- nd sophomores. Seniors and juniors will be free, to take the course
or 'not, as they feel disposed.
(Continued on page 8, cot. 2)'

In addition to the practical drills
and military maneuvers to be given
in the course ill military training
at this University this year and
next, a course will also be offered,
beginning next fall, in the theoretical consideration of military formations and problems. This course
may be taken as part fulfillment. of
the work necessary to graduation,
and credit for it will be given in
the same way as for any purely
academic study in the present curriculum.
Dean Brush has recently received
a letter from the War Department
taking up in detail the subjects required for the entire course prescribed for the reserve officers'
training corps. • The subjects are
as follows:
(I) Infantry Drill Regulations.
—To include definition,. general
principles, drills, ceremonies, etc.,
which a company officer must know.
School of the soldier, school of the
squad, school of the company,
school of s the battalion (includes
extended Order).
(2) Manual of Interior Guard.
Duty—To include definitions, general principles and practice in
guard. duty.
(3) Physical Drills—To include
calisthenics, bayonet exercise and
bayonet combat.
(4) Military Hygiene—To include the principles of personal hygiene, camp sanitation, first aid to
the injurcd, etc.
(5) Field Service Regulations
--To include • definitions, general
prhiciples, etc.; marching and
camping. patrolling, advance
guards, flank guards, rear guards,
attack and defense, outposts, organization, administration (Parts
I, II and III).
(Continued on page 5, col. I)

GOVERNOR TO HOPKINS' AID
Takes Stand Against Proposed Cut in
Annual Grant by Legislature Hopkins May Lose Only $5,000
Instead of $25,000.

Due to pleas made by President
Goodnow, former Speaker Trippe
and other men and to the decision
of Governor Harrington to intervene in the University's behalf, it
now seems as though the annual
grant of the Maryland Legislature
to Hopkins will only be reduced
by $5,000, instead of by $25,000
as was first planned.
Governor Harrington took his
stand in defense of the appropriation after a plea made to him last
week by Dr. Goodnow, Dr. Welch,
Mr. B. Howell Griswold,. Jr., Mr.
Daniel Willard and Mr. R. Brent
Keyser. In the Legislature, opposition to the proposed cut is centering about Senator James Archer, who, though himself a Prince'ton man, is doing everything in his
power to prevent the reduction.
Two other men who are doing
their best to allow the grant to be
passed in its form of previous years
are State Senator William Milnes
Maloy and Attorney-General Albert C. Ritchie. Both of these men
have gone before the Finance and
Ways and Means Committees and
asked that Hopkins be given its
customary grant of $75,000 in
toto, and have also interviewed
those Senators reported to be in
favor of the cut.
Former Speaker James McC.
Trippe, a Hopkins graduate and a
leader in the movement which resulted in the passing of the Technical School Bill, is also working
hard for Hopkins.
•
Mr. Trippe pointed out to the
Legislature that when it was agreed
to give Hopkins $50,o00 to cover
free scholarship, the University at
the same time agreed as a part of
the contract that is would pay the
administrative and other overhead
charges of running the technological school. The former Speaker declared that the institution cannot
possibly grant the free scholarships
and pay the administrative expenses
out of the $50,000 scholarship fund.
1916 Hullabaloo Soon to Go to Printer.

The work on the 1916 Hullabaloo is being rushed in order to get
all the material to the printer by
April 1, so that the book may be
issued by May 1.
The first pictures have been received from the White Studio, and
have been' Sent -to the engraver.
The rest of the pictures are expected to arrive this week. The
biographies of the members of the
Senior class, and the various
stories, are coming in steadily,

Advisory Editor of "Nation" To Come to
Hopkins on March 29 to Deliver
Course of Lectures Under
Turnbull Foundation.

The twenty-first course of lectures under the Turnbull Foundation will be given by Paul Elmer
More, A. M., LL.D., on the general
subject of "Poets of America." The
series will begin on Wednesday,
March 29, with "The Spirit and
Poetry of Early New England."
The schedule of the other lectures
is as follows:
Friday, March 31.
Emerson
Monday, April 3
Whittier and Longfellow
'
Wednesday, April 5
The Influences of New York
Friday, April 7
Three Poets of the South
Monday, April io...Sidney Lanier
Wednesday, April 12
The Modern Movement
The Percy Turnbull Memorial
Lectures on Poetry were instituted
in 1889 by Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence
Turnbull in memory of their son,
Percy Graeme Turnbull. The purpose of the foundation is that an
annual course of lectures on poetry
may be given by one of "the properly qualified authors, writers or
professors of America or Europe."
Paul Elmer More, the lecturer of
this year, was Associate Professor
of Sanskrit at Harvard and at Bryn
Mawr, and later the literay editor
of "The Independent." Since 1903
he has served in the latter capacity
on the staff of the New York
"Evening Post," and since 1909 he
has been Advisory Editor of "The
Nation." Mr. More is also the
author of an admirable translation
of the "Promethus Bound" of
yEschylus, of a life of Benjamin
Franklin, and of the "Shelburne
Essays."
The series was given last year
by Sir Walter Raleigh, D. Litt.,
LL.D., of the University of Oxford, his subject being "Poetry and
Criticism of the Romantic Revival." Among other lecturers under
this foundation have been Edmund
C. Stedman, Professor Charles
Eliot Norton, Hamilton Wright
Mabie, Dr. Henry Van Dyke, and
Professor George Lyman Kittredge.

SPRING SEASON OPENS SATURDAY

1916 APPOINTS COMMITTEES

SALES-CHECKS REACH HIGH MARK

Lacrosse Schedule Begins With Alumni
•Game—Carlisle and Harvard Will
Not Be Met this Year—Team
in Good Shape.

Senior Banquet to Take Place Before
Easter Class Day, Prom and
"Party" Committees
Appointed.

Thousand Dollars Represented in Final
Returns of News-Letter Contest A.
K. Chalmers Winner—Another
to Be Held Later in Year.

The lacrosse season officially
opens next Saturday afternoon,
when the 'Varsity plays the
Alumni on Homewood field, and
on every Saturday afternoon thereafter, until May 13th (omitting
May 6th) there will be lacrosse
contests staged at Homewood.
The schedule this year is slightly different from that of last season. On the Saturday following
the Alumni game Hopkins meets
Cornell. It will be recalled that
the game. with Cornell last year
had to be cancelled, owing to a
snowstorm. After Cornell, the
'Varsity plays Penn State on
April 15th; then Navy on Wednesday, April 19th, at Annapolis;
Pennsylvania on Saturday, the
22nd, at Homewood, and Stevens
on the 29th. The team will journey to South Bethlehem to play
Lehigh on May 6th. As Lehigh
has proved to be an uncertain
proposition for the Hopkins
twelve .during the past few years,
this is regarded as the hardest
game on the schedule. The last
game of the season will be played
at Homewood on May 13th, when
Hopkins meets Swarthmore.
Hopkins is not scheduled to
play Carlisle or Harvard this season, but instead meets Penn State
and Stevens. Carlisle has dropped
all forms of athletics, while conflicting dates prevented Hopkins
and Harvard from meeting this
year.
The squad held their first practice out of doors about a week
ago. Up to this time all the practices have been held in the cage.
For the present, the squad is compelled to use the old Country.
School field until Homewood and
Straus fields are in proper condition. It is only a matter of a day
or so, however, until the players
will have the Gilman field for the
regular grounds at Homewood.
A number of Alumni have lately joined the squad in order to get
in trim for the game scheduled for
this Saturday, and if the results of
previous years are to be depended
upon, the contest is sure to be
very closely contested. Coach Raney Wolfe, Assistant Coaches
Tom Troxell and John Huck, Eddie Hulbert, the Schmeisser brothers and many other former, stars
will be in the lineup for the
Alumni.
With the first game less than
one week off, the regular members
of the squad are engaged in the
hardest work of the season. The
coaches are pleased with the improvement made by many of the
new players. 'Two of them—
Schmidt and Meyer—are fighting
hard for positions on the defense.
Stuart continues to hold down the
goal position and has an able assistant in Chalmers. Liebensperger, Baker, Brooks, Hoffman and

A meeting of the Senior Class
was held last Wednesday, March
22, at which various class matters
were discussed and several committees were appointed. The first matter brought up after the meeting
had been called to order by President Tingley was the re-enacting of
the hazing scenes of 1914. A debate arose as to whether it was
more advisable to use the old pictures taken at the time of the hazing or to use the new pictures which
were taken last Saturday at Homewood. The matter was finally left
to the committee which has charge
of the re-enacting, of which L. R.
Vickers, the class photographer, is
chairman.
The question of the Senior banquet was not brought up. President
Tingley appointed the following
committee: McDowell, chaiernan ;
\Tickers, Ludington and Bagley. It
was then determined to have the
banquet some time before the Easter holidays.
The other committees which were
appointed to take charge of the
coming spring events of the Senior
class were the Class Day, Senior
Prom and Senior "Party" Committees. The Class Day Committee is
composed of Frick, chairman; Hall
and Primrose; the Senior Prom
Committee is made up of Myron C.
Bagley, chairman; Woodward,
Hardy and Beck, and the Senior
"Party" Committee consists of
Vickers, chairman; Leitheiser,
Tingley and Knipp.

TIM NEWS-LETTER sales-check
contest ended on Saturday, March
18, with Mr. Allan K. Chalmers,
the winner, with checks for $387.70.
Mr., R. Leibensperger took second
place with $139.15, and Mr. W.
Royston Smith came third with
$119.95. The total amount of
checks came up to the thousand
dollar mark. The first prize will be
a $6 Gillette safety razor; the others have not yet been announced.
While the total of checks turned
in for this contest was not so high
as that of the contest held last year,
the business management of THE
NEWS-LETTER feels that it has
every reason to be satisfied with its
results. The more successful contest of last year was the second
one of the season, and, in addition,
the time of students who might
otherwise have taken part in the
recent competition was ocCupied
with examinations.
For these reasons, it has been
decided to hold another contest
later in the year. The time of the
closing of this contest will be announced later; meanwhile, all students are advised to accumulate all
sales-checks returned from their
purchases.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 27, 1916.

Managing Editor for this number, Reuben Oppenheimer, '18.
The Installation of Military Training.

Military training has come; Hopkins has definitely taken its stand
as favoring the nation-wide movement for preparedness and for the
development of the college men of
the country which that movement
bears with it. It has been a momentous decision; how momentous,
it may be left for future generations to realize. For us, the present students, only one realization
is possible; we have volunteered
in full consciousness of the meaning of the act to train ourselves
for actual service beneath our country's flag.
There is no honor and no avail
in attempting to blind ourselves to
the full significance of the Course
whose installation . this week has
witnessed. Those of us who, next
year, take the full course offered
under the act by which the course
has been inaugurated, will place
ourselves under jurisdiction of the
United States Department of War,
and if Avar ever comes, we shall be
considered among the first reserve
forces of the nation.
The course in military training
has been installed at Hopkins for
two reasons. The first is for the
actual- training which it gives, for
the benefit to muscle and mind
which only the rigor or drill can
impart. That such benefit Cioes accrue is undeniable. There is no better development of the body obtain-

able than that furnished by, the
United States Army. And the discipline of command, the co-ordination of individuals and the submission of the part to the whole in one
united movement is a lesson which
no other organization existent can
better teach.
But the real cause of the installation of the course goes back to a
far higher motive than any thought
of personal development. Americans are accused, perhaps justly, of
a suppression of emotion, and
against our colleges especially is
this accusation aimed-we are
charged with a distaste for the
recognition of any feeling which
has a root deeper than the trivial
and superficial. That the implication is in some sense just is proved
by the hesitancy with "which we
proclaim, our true motive in welcoming. this course by the almost
bashful haste with which we are
already prone to take it as a matter
of course. Yet the gravity of our
act over-rides all traditions-we
must acknowledge and acknowledge triumphantly the real motive
of our decision. Hopkins is welcoming military training because
of one paramount desire-it wishes
to serve and -to protect its country.
Brickley's Resignation.

The entire University experienced a genuine and profound sense
of regret when announcement was
made that Chas. Brickley would not
coach the Hopkins eleven this fall.
That regret was partly for the setback which Brickley's resignation
has given to Hopkins' football
plans; but, even more, it was a
sense of sincere disappointment for
the loss of the man himself.
Brickley came to Hopkins last
year at a time when our football
Prospects were perhaps darker than.
they have been at any time since the
University's foundation; he faced
obstacles which, to many men,
would have seemed insurmountable.
Yet, with a squad of men almost ludicrously small in proportion to the
squads of larger institutions, with
time for practice greatly restricted,
and with the entire absence of that
dormitory life which is so essential
to the development of a team, he
succeeded in turning out an eleven
which won the championship of the
State, and which showed in every
game it played a vigor and spirit
and dash of which any college could
well afford to he proud.
Hopkins was already counting itself fortunate in securing Brickley's
services for the coaching of next
year's team, when the Athletic Association made its announcement.
Yet, however much the University
may have counted - on his work,
however great may have been the
holies of what another year under
his guidance might be able to produce, however much the plans of
the Association may have been disorganized, there is no reason and
no excuse for believing that the
progress of the football team itself
has been in any way stopped..Work

such as Brickley performed last fait
cannot go for naught; he himself
may not be able to Coach the eleven
next season, but the spirit and the
determination which he instilled
into every member of last season's
squad will make itself felt again.
Hopkins has awakened, and , although it deplores the absence Of
the man who awakened it, it has
too much confidence, both in the
caliber of its players and in the
judgment of those controlling its
football destinies, to fear that the
showing made by the team last year
Will prove to be anything but a beginning.
Hopkins appreciates the work,
Charles Brickley has done far too
much to wish that he should follow
any course which would interfere
in any way with his future prospects; and although his offer before the Athletic Board was in accord with the fine courtesy and
sportsmanship which he has always shown, the entire student
body agrees, as a matter of course,
with the instantaneous decision of
the Board, not to hold him to the
letter of his agreement. It was desired, above all things, that Brickley
could find it convenient to return
here next year. That desire has
proved to be incapable of fulfilment,
and so all the appreciation which
every student feels for what he has
done, all the admiration and respect and friendship which, within
the short space of four months, he
succeeded in arousing among us,
must go into a sincere and universal wish that this future life will
be attended by all the success of
which he has shown himself worthy
at this University.
In Foreign Lands.

Occasionally, to both Hopkins
men, somewhat blinded by familiarity, and to the nation, somewhat
prone to indifference to collegiate
reputation, there comes a striking
confirmation of all the high scholarship and intellectual attainment for
which Johns Hopkins University
has always stood. Such a confirmation is the untold action of the
Chinese Government in calling Dr.
Willoughby to China and in asking
President Goodnow to retain the
post of constitutional advisor.
The honor is paid primarily to
the men called upon to occupy these
positions, but in recognition of the
abilities of these men the Chinese
Government is also recognizing the
worth of Hopkins standards and
the reputation which this University everywhere enjoys. It is an
honor which comes but once in a
generation, and which is all the
more meaningful in that it is paid
by a nation which. is but beginning
to realize itself and which needs
counsel at this petiod more than it
ever has ill the entire course of its
history.

The most cordial relationship has
always existed between Hopkins
and the men at the head of Chinese
scholarship and progress. China
looks to this institution perhaps as

much as to any other in this country for the furtherance of that interchange of ideals which is essential to the thorough understanding
of one country by another. Th(
positions of President Goodnow
and Dr. Willoughby are significant
not only for the recognition whiclthey pay to this University's attainments, but for the promise ol
friendly and mutual developmetv
which they bear to both China anc
the United States and to the world

BALTIMORE, MD.

The latest report of the Rockefeller General Education Board
states • that the full-time plan of
Instruction inaugurated several
years ago at the Johns Hopkins
Hospital through the million-dollar fund given by the Board has,
in every way, justified the expectations which were made at its installation. This plan provides, in
brief, that the professors in the various branches of medicine, surgery and pediatrics, spend all of
their time at the hospital and
medical school, withdrawing . entirely from private practice.
The report of the Board states
that the transition from the old
arrangement to the new was made
with
any friction whatever.
Every interest concerned, it proceeds, has benefited by the change.
The younger men especially have
opportunity of working in closer
and more constant association
with the full-time • professors, • for
as they obtain their training from
the departmental heads, their opportunities to learn are vastly
greater when their head chief devotes all his time to the hospital.
The fact that no professor
working under the present arrang,ement has any outside demands has caw,.ed the weekly
meetings of. the various departments to be excellently attended,
not only by the students, but by
directors of the full-time departments and their assistants. The
men who are doing research work
in the laboratories also contribute
to the disc,ussions. Such a conference could have been before only
irregularly attended.

two consic-lerations, the contestants

Martin J. Vincent will serve as two
of the judges. The name of the
third judge has not as yet been announced.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 27, 1916.

8

TO INVESTIGATE PRISON CAMPS MADE ADVISOR TO NEW EMPIRE
Hopkins Doctors, at Request of Great
Britain, Leave for Germany to
Make Report on State
of Prisoners.

Dr. Willoughby to Go to China to Help
Government—Pres. Goodnow, Acting
in Baltimore, to Retain Post of
Constitutional Advisor.

Two Hopkins doctors, Dr. S. V.
Irwin, '14, of Oakland, Cal., and
Dr. J. P. Webster, '13, of Plymouth, N. H., have been chosen by
the State Department to go to Germany for the purpose of inspecting
some of that country's great prison
camps. These men are now on
their way to Berlin, where they will
report to the American Red Cross
headquarters at the American Embassy.
The English Government, after
receiving many reports concerning
the harsh treatment of German
prisdners, requested the State Department of this country to name
two surgeons to visit the British
prison camps in Germany. Before
any doctors could be sent, it was
necessary to obtain permission from
the German Imperial Government
for these men to visit the camps.
The German military authorities, it
is said, however, welcomed an opportunity to have the prisons inspected by impartial observers; and
so readily granted the request.
Doctors Irwin and Webster will,
therefore, have access to all the immense prison camps, where thousands of British, French and Belgium prisoners are confined.
The Bal'imoreans will devote
most of their time to the British
camps and their reports will be
made to London. It is likely that
a report of the conduct of the
camps, the sanitary arrangements
and other details will also be made
to the American Red Cross.

Dr. W. W. Willoughby, a professor of political science at this
University, has announc,ed that
he is going to leave for China
about May 1 to act as advisor to
the Chinese Government.
Yuan Shi Kai, the ex-president
and present Emperor of China,
has renewed the agreement with
Dr. Goodnow, the president of
Johns Hopkins University, by
which Dr. Goodnow remains the
constitutional advisor of the empire. In this manner there will be
two Hopkins men aiding the newly formed empire; Dr. Willoughby in Pekin, and Dr. Goodnow in
Baltimore. There will be no special fields of governmental activity to which the men will devote
their attention, but they will give
their advice on any problems
which may be submitted to them.
Dr. Willoughby has been granted permission to go to China by
the Board of Trustees.
When his work there is finished
he will return to the University.

PROF. CHRISTIE LECTURES:- ON
ROCKY MOUNTAINS OF CANADA

An excellent lecture was given
last Monday evening in McCoy
Hall by Prof. A. G. Christie on
"The Rocky Mountains of Canada." The many magnificent pictures with which the talk was illustrated proved equally interesting.
Views were shown later of
spots such as Lake Louise, and
the Selkirks, familiar to all tourists; and of the more secluded
places visited only by the campers. There were also some remarkable views of mountain
climbing, of the Glaciers, and of
the few remaining wild animals
of the Northwest.
In the majesty of its mountains,
in the beauty of its glaciers and
lakes, the Rockies of Canada, said
the lecturer, may well be compared with the scenery of Switzerland.

will have military training was outlined in the Senate Chamber on
March 18 by Senator Hardwick,
its sponsor, as follows:
"Whenever the authorities of any
school or college shall apply for
Federal aid in the establishment of
a military organization, and shall
furnish a statement that so or more
young men or boys, students at
their institution, above the age of
15 and with the consent of their
parents in the case of minors, have
declared their willingness to join,
their statement shall be investigated
by the War Department, and, if

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 27, 1916.

TENNIS SCHEDULE ANNOUNCED

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG

Practice of Team Already Under Way
New Material on Hand to Fill
Up Loss of Former
Players.

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

The spring practice of the Johns
Hopkins University Tennis Team
has already begun, and with the addition of a number of new stars the
prospects of the success of the
team this year are unusually
bright.
The men who played on the team
last year are Sydney Morgan, A.
L. Hammond, the present manager; Walter Taylor, the present
captain; Erwin /Roach, Peyton
Strobel, W. R. Jacobsen, and M.
R. McLean. Of these, Morgan,
Roach and McLean have left the
University. The loss of Morgan is
especially felt, as he was a star
player, having held the championship of the University for the past
three years.
With these old men as a nucleus,
however, and with the addition of
Warren .Allen, captain of last
year's City College team; W. L.
Linton, of last year's - four of
the West Virginia team; Flowers, Medical School, of last
year's Wesleyan team; Webster, Medical School, of Amherst;
William Love, Simeon Kloskey,
Joel Gutman, F. K. Ebaugh, Michael School and others, Hopkins
has no cause to deplore the lack
of available material.
A. L. Hammond, the manager of
this year's team, has arranged an
especially strong and attractive
schedule. The first game is played
on April 15, and the last one is
scheduled on June io, soon after
the closing of the final term. The
schedule is as follows:
April 15—Gettysburg, at Gettysburg.
April 19—Navy, at Annapolis.
April 2I—Princeton, at FIomewood.
April 28—Trinity, at H o m ewood. •
May 6--Catholic University, at
Washington.
May io--Haverford, at Homewood.
May Tr—Virginia, at H o m ewood.
May I2—University of P e n nsy.lvania, at Philadelphia.
May 13—Rutgers, at New
Brunswick. .
May 19—Michigan, at H o m ewood.
May 20—Georgetown, at Washing-ton.
May 27—St. John's, at Annapolis.
June io--Washington College,
at Chestertown.

A Criticism of the Inter-fraternity Board.

THE NV's-LETTER:
Is the r916 Inter - Fraternity
Board justifying its existence? The
first Board was organized with the
primary purpose of setting up satisfactory rules to govern "rushing". This is the year 1916, and
the heir of those earlier days is still
setting up rules to govern rushing.
Surely by this time the stress of
organizing need no longer claim its
attention. And could one dare suggest that a Board chosen from the
best that the Fraternities have to
offer, either does not care enough
or has not vision enough to confront and seek as an inter-fraternity body a solution for other and
more intimate problems of fraternity life?
It is the fond desire of those who
have once served on boards or
councils to gracefully and gratefully pass the toga to others, and
then to slip out to be one of that
"silent succession" that has already
gone on. That, some consider, is
the height of wisdom. First, it
saves trouble. And then, too, none
call remark that trite but everforceful: "Why don't you mind
your own business ?"
I beg for this day to be one
apart from that "silent succession,"
and to boldly ask why fraternity
men at Hopkins, as a body, have
never considered, for instance, the
question of Fraternity Scholarship.
Lo, and we see an excited gentleman in the far corner arise and
exclaim without taking breath:(1)
"We maintain our scholarship
through committees working within the separate fraternities." (2)
"How could we improve on that?"
(3) "Anyway, that's not the InterFraternity Board's business."
The excited gentleman, of course,
demands an answer. Suppose we
say to( )that the spur to scholarship under a committee plan in the
separate fraternity is, as a rule, only
as vivid as the personality of the
chairman of the committee, and
consequently the stimulation of
scholarship will fluctuate violently
—and often, lamentably. (3) You
say that is not the business of the
Inter-Fraternity Board :- Do you

VOL. XX, NO. 21.

BRICKLEY RESIGNS POSITION
Coach of Last Year's Championship Eleven Asks to Be Relc ased from Contract, Due to Pressure of
Business Obligations.

It has been officially announced
that Charles E. Brickley will not
be Hopkins football coach again
next fall.
The Johns Hopkins Football
Committee had not announced, at
time of going to press, who would
succeed Brickley, but report has it
that "Hank" Brennick will be given
the position. Brickley will coach
Boston College next year.
The statement given out by the
Football Committee is as follows:
"Mr. Charles Brickley, of Harvard, who coached the Johns Hopkins University football team last
year, appeared before the Football
Committee of the University today
(March 13), and stated that subsequent to his signing of the contract
to coach at Hopkins next year he
had made business connections in
Boston, which an absence of three
months to coach at Johns Hopkins
would seriouSly jeopardize."
After a full talk with Mr. Brickley, the committee informed him
that .they would recommend, although with keen regret, that his
resignation be accepted by the Athletic Board of the University,• on
the grounds that they ,were unwilling that his • contract to coach
Johns Hopkins next year should
interfere with his permanant business prospects.
-Mr. Brickley informed the committee that he would probably do
some coaching at Harvard during
the coming fall, but that this would
be of such a nature that it would
not interfere with his business
plans.
The Football Committee is considering the appointment of Mr.
Brickley's successor, as well as an
assistant coach.
Y. M. C. A. TO ELECT OFFICERS
AT GENERAL MASS-MEETING

The annual election of officers of
the Young Men's Christian Association of this University will take
place sometime this week in the
chapel of Levering Hall. Contrary
to the usual custom, the officers
Nv ill be elected in a mass-meeting
of all the interested students.
This action is taken as part of
the campaign on the part of the Y.
M. C. A. to have the students feel
that the Association is one of their
own institutions, and that they have
an interest in its organization. A
large attendance is expected for this
meeting. which is by far the most
important of the year.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 27, 1916.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

MILITARY TRAINING BEGINS THIS WEEK
Drills to Take Place Both in Gymnasium and at Homewood Under
Direction of Mr. Kistler—Course Entirely Voluntary,
But in Future to Be Compulsory for
Freshmen and Sophomores.
This Monday witnessed the installation of military training at Johns
Hopkins University. It is just possible that unforeseen developments
may postpone the actual commencement of the course until next week;
but it is. almost assured that, by the time this issue reaches the hands of
its readers, military training will have already begun.
Until the special officer detailed by the War Department reaches here,
the men will be put under Mr. Theodore Kistler, the present gymnasium
instructor. The . first part of the training will consist in rudimentary
drills and setting-up exercises. It is probable that guns and uniforms
will be on hand before the end of the year. _
The men volunteering to take the course this spring will rest under
no legal obligation. Beginning next year, however, those taking the
full course provided by the Government for the establishment of a
Reserve Officers Corps will form part of the reserve of the United
States military forces.
1\1H:tory training will begin at
Johns Hopkins University this
Monday.
Definite announcement to this effect was made a few days ago by
Dean Brush. The requisite number of students have volunteered
to take the course this spring, the
War College has given its approval
to the movement, and all preparations are rapidly • being completed
for the installation of the course before .the next fortnight has elapsed.
The officer who is to be detailed
by the War Department to take
charge of the Hopkins corps has
not yet been appointed, and until
his arrival, the men will be put under the charge of the present gymnasium instructor, Mr. Theodore
Kistler. The first few weeks of
drill must inevitably be devoted to
practice in rudimentary formations
and to setting-up exercises, and
Mr. Kistler has amply demonstrated
his proficiency in instruction -along
these lines to o long succession of
freshman classes.
- It is planned to form two squads
of the men this spring, one to drill
in the cage, and the other, composed chiefly of the engineering
students, to drill at Homewood.
These arrangements are, of course,
only temporary. When the officer
appointed by the War Department
arrives, it. is expected that the men
will be far enough advanced to permit of the formation of the regular
student corps.
The drills will be held every
Monday, Wednesday and Friday
.afternoon at 5 o'clock.
Although participation in the
course will be entirely voluntary
this year, beginning nest fall, it will
be made compulsory for freshmen
a
- nd sophomores. Seniors and juniors will be free, to take the course
or 'not, as they feel disposed.
(Continued on page 8, cot. 2)'

In addition to the practical drills
and military maneuvers to be given
in the course ill military training
at this University this year and
next, a course will also be offered,
beginning next fall, in the theoretical consideration of military formations and problems. This course
may be taken as part fulfillment. of
the work necessary to graduation,
and credit for it will be given in
the same way as for any purely
academic study in the present curriculum.
Dean Brush has recently received
a letter from the War Department
taking up in detail the subjects required for the entire course prescribed for the reserve officers'
training corps. • The subjects are
as follows:
(I) Infantry Drill Regulations.
—To include definition,. general

GOVERNOR TO HOPKINS' AID
Takes Stand Against Proposed Cut in
Annual Grant by Legislature Hopkins May Lose Only $5,000
Instead of $25,000.

Due to pleas made by President
Goodnow, former Speaker Trippe
and other men and to the decision
of Governor Harrington to intervene in the University's behalf, it
now seems as though the annual
grant of the Maryland Legislature
to Hopkins will only be reduced
by $5,000, instead of by $25,000
as was first planned.
Governor Harrington took his
stand in defense of the appropriation after a plea made to him last
week by Dr. Goodnow, Dr. Welch,
Mr. B. Howell Griswold,. Jr., Mr.
Daniel Willard and Mr. R. Brent
Keyser. In the Legislature, opposition to the proposed cut is centering about Senator James Archer, who, though himself a Prince'ton man, is doing everything in his
power to prevent the reduction.
Two other men who are doing
their best to allow the grant to be
passed in its form of previous years
are State Senator William Milnes
Maloy and Attorney-General Albert C. Ritchie. Both of these men
have gone before the Finance and
Ways and Means Committees and
asked that Hopkins be given its
customary grant of $75,000 in
toto, and have also interviewed
those Senators reported to be in
favor of the cut.
Former Speaker James McC.
Trippe, a Hopkins graduate and a
leader in the movement which resulted in the passing of the Technical School Bill, is also working
hard for Hopkins.
•
Mr. Trippe pointed out to the
Legislature that when it was agreed
to give Hopkins $50,o00 to cover
free scholarship, the University at
the same time agreed as a part of
the contract that is would pay the
administrative and other overhead
charges of running the technological school. The former Speaker declared that the institution cannot
possibly grant the free scholarships
and pay the administrative expenses
out of the $50,000 scholarship fund.

Advisory Editor of "Nation" To Come to
Hopkins on March 29 to Deliver
Course of Lectures Under
Turnbull Foundation.

The twenty-first course of lectures under the Turnbull Foundation will be given by Paul Elmer
More, A. M., LL.D., on the general
subject of "Poets of America." The
series will begin on Wednesday,
March 29, with "The Spirit and
Poetry of Early New England."
The schedule of the other lectures
is as follows:
Friday, March 31.
Emerson
Monday, April 3
Whittier and Longfellow
'
Wednesday, April 5
The Influences of New York
Friday, April 7
Three Poets of the South
Monday, April io...Sidney Lanier
Wednesday, April 12
The Modern Movement
The Percy Turnbull Memorial
Lectures on Poetry were instituted
in 1889 by Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence
Turnbull in memory of their son,
Percy Graeme Turnbull. The purpose of the foundation is that an
annual course of lectures on poetry
may be given by one of "the properly qualified authors, writers or
professors of America or Europe."
Paul Elmer More, the lecturer of
this year, was Associate Professor
of Sanskrit at Harvard and at Bryn
Mawr, and later the literay editor
of "The Independent." Since 1903
he has served in the latter capacity
on the staff of the New York
"Evening Post," and since 1909 he
has been Advisory Editor of "The
Nation." Mr. More is also the
author of an admirable translation
of the "Promethus Bound" of
yEschylus, of a life of Benjamin
Franklin, and of the "Shelburne
Essays."
The series was given last year
by Sir Walter Raleigh, D. Litt.,
LL.D., of the University of Oxford, his subject being "Poetry and
Criticism of the Romantic Revival." Among other lecturers under
this foundation have been Edmund
C. Stedman, Professor Charles
Eliot Norton, Hamilton Wright
Mabie, Dr. Henry Van Dyke, and
Professor George Lyman Kittredge.

1916 APPOINTS COMMITTEES

SALES-CHECKS REACH HIGH MARK

Lacrosse Schedule Begins With Alumni
•Game—Carlisle and Harvard Will
Not Be Met this Year—Team
in Good Shape.

Senior Banquet to Take Place Before
Easter Class Day, Prom and
"Party" Committees
Appointed.

Thousand Dollars Represented in Final
Returns of News-Letter Contest A.
K. Chalmers Winner—Another
to Be Held Later in Year.

The lacrosse season officially
opens next Saturday afternoon,
when the 'Varsity plays the
Alumni on Homewood field, and
on every Saturday afternoon thereafter, until May 13th (omitting
May 6th) there will be lacrosse
contests staged at Homewood.
The schedule this year is slightly different from that of last season. On the Saturday following
the Alumni game Hopkins meets
Cornell. It will be recalled that
the game. with Cornell last year
had to be cancelled, owing to a
snowstorm. After Cornell, the
'Varsity plays Penn State on
April 15th; then Navy on Wednesday, April 19th, at Annapolis;
Pennsylvania on Saturday, the
22nd, at Homewood, and Stevens
on the 29th. The team will journey to South Bethlehem to play
Lehigh on May 6th. As Lehigh
has proved to be an uncertain
proposition for the Hopkins
twelve .during the past few years,
this is regarded as the hardest
game on the schedule. The last
game of the season will be played
at Homewood on May 13th, when
Hopkins meets Swarthmore.
Hopkins is not scheduled to
play Carlisle or Harvard this season, but instead meets Penn State
and Stevens. Carlisle has dropped
all forms of athletics, while conflicting dates prevented Hopkins
and Harvard from meeting this
year.
The squad held their first practice out of doors about a week
ago. Up to this time all the practices have been held in the cage.
For the present, the squad is compelled to use the old Country.
School field until Homewood and
Straus fields are in proper condition. It is only a matter of a day
or so, however, until the players
will have the Gilman field for the
regular grounds at Homewood.
A number of Alumni have lately joined the squad in order to get
in trim for the game scheduled for
this Saturday, and if the results of
previous years are to be depended
upon, the contest is sure to be
very closely contested. Coach Raney Wolfe, Assistant Coaches
Tom Troxell and John Huck, Eddie Hulbert, the Schmeisser brothers and many other former, stars
will be in the lineup for the
Alumni.
With the first game less than
one week off, the regular members
of the squad are engaged in the
hardest work of the season. The
coaches are pleased with the improvement made by many of the
new players. 'Two of them—
Schmidt and Meyer—are fighting
hard for positions on the defense.
Stuart continues to hold down the
goal position and has an able assistant in Chalmers. Liebensperger, Baker, Brooks, Hoffman and

A meeting of the Senior Class
was held last Wednesday, March
22, at which various class matters
were discussed and several committees were appointed. The first matter brought up after the meeting
had been called to order by President Tingley was the re-enacting of
the hazing scenes of 1914. A debate arose as to whether it was
more advisable to use the old pictures taken at the time of the hazing or to use the new pictures which
were taken last Saturday at Homewood. The matter was finally left
to the committee which has charge
of the re-enacting, of which L. R.
Vickers, the class photographer, is
chairman.
The question of the Senior banquet was not brought up. President
Tingley appointed the following
committee: McDowell, chaiernan ;
\Tickers, Ludington and Bagley. It
was then determined to have the
banquet some time before the Easter holidays.
The other committees which were
appointed to take charge of the
coming spring events of the Senior
class were the Class Day, Senior
Prom and Senior "Party" Committees. The Class Day Committee is
composed of Frick, chairman; Hall
and Primrose; the Senior Prom
Committee is made up of Myron C.
Bagley, chairman; Woodward,
Hardy and Beck, and the Senior
"Party" Committee consists of
Vickers, chairman; Leitheiser,
Tingley and Knipp.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 27, 1916.

Managing Editor for this number, Reuben Oppenheimer, '18.
The Installation of Military Training.

Military training has come; Hopkins has definitely taken its stand
as favoring the nation-wide movement for preparedness and for the
development of the college men of
the country which that movement
bears with it. It has been a momentous decision; how momentous,
it may be left for future generations to realize. For us, the present students, only one realization
is possible; we have volunteered
in full consciousness of the meaning of the act to train ourselves
for actual service beneath our country's flag.
There is no honor and no avail
in attempting to blind ourselves to
the full significance of the Course
whose installation . this week has
witnessed. Those of us who, next
year, take the full course offered
under the act by which the course
has been inaugurated, will place
ourselves under jurisdiction of the
United States Department of War,
and if Avar ever comes, we shall be
considered among the first reserve
forces of the nation.
The course in military training
has been installed at Hopkins for
two reasons. The first is for the
actual- training which it gives, for
the benefit to muscle and mind
which only the rigor or drill can
impart. That such benefit Cioes accrue is undeniable. There is no better development of the body obtain-

able than that furnished by, the
United States Army. And the discipline of command, the co-ordination of individuals and the submission of the part to the whole in one
united movement is a lesson which
no other organization existent can
better teach.
But the real cause of the installation of the course goes back to a
far higher motive than any thought
of personal development. Americans are accused, perhaps justly, of
a suppression of emotion, and
against our colleges especially is
this accusation aimed-we are
charged with a distaste for the
recognition of any feeling which
has a root deeper than the trivial
and superficial. That the implication is in some sense just is proved
by the hesitancy with "which we
proclaim, our true motive in welcoming. this course by the almost
bashful haste with which we are
already prone to take it as a matter
of course. Yet the gravity of our
act over-rides all traditions-we
must acknowledge and acknowledge triumphantly the real motive
of our decision. Hopkins is welcoming military training because
of one paramount desire-it wishes
to serve and -to protect its country.
Brickley's Resignation.

The entire University experienced a genuine and profound sense
of regret when announcement was
made that Chas. Brickley would not
coach the Hopkins eleven this fall.
That regret was partly for the setback which Brickley's resignation
has given to Hopkins' football
plans; but, even more, it was a
sense of sincere disappointment for
the loss of the man himself.
Brickley came to Hopkins last
year at a time when our football
Prospects were perhaps darker than.
they have been at any time since the
University's foundation; he faced
obstacles which, to many men,
would have seemed insurmountable.
Yet, with a squad of men almost ludicrously small in proportion to the
squads of larger institutions, with
time for practice greatly restricted,
and with the entire absence of that
dormitory life which is so essential
to the development of a team, he
succeeded in turning out an eleven
which won the championship of the
State, and which showed in every
game it played a vigor and spirit
and dash of which any college could
well afford to he proud.
Hopkins was already counting itself fortunate in securing Brickley's
services for the coaching of next
year's team, when the Athletic Association made its announcement.
Yet, however much the University
may have counted - on his work,
however great may have been the
holies of what another year under
his guidance might be able to produce, however much the plans of
the Association may have been disorganized, there is no reason and
no excuse for believing that the
progress of the football team itself
has been in any way stopped..Work

such as Brickley performed last fait
cannot go for naught; he himself
may not be able to Coach the eleven
next season, but the spirit and the
determination which he instilled
into every member of last season's
squad will make itself felt again.
Hopkins has awakened, and , although it deplores the absence Of
the man who awakened it, it has
too much confidence, both in the
caliber of its players and in the
judgment of those controlling its
football destinies, to fear that the
showing made by the team last year
Will prove to be anything but a beginning.
Hopkins appreciates the work,
Charles Brickley has done far too
much to wish that he should follow
any course which would interfere
in any way with his future prospects; and although his offer before the Athletic Board was in accord with the fine courtesy and
sportsmanship which he has always shown, the entire student
body agrees, as a matter of course,
with the instantaneous decision of
the Board, not to hold him to the
letter of his agreement. It was desired, above all things, that Brickley
could find it convenient to return
here next year. That desire has
proved to be incapable of fulfilment,
and so all the appreciation which
every student feels for what he has
done, all the admiration and respect and friendship which, within
the short space of four months, he
succeeded in arousing among us,
must go into a sincere and universal wish that this future life will
be attended by all the success of
which he has shown himself worthy
at this University.
In Foreign Lands.

Occasionally, to both Hopkins
men, somewhat blinded by familiarity, and to the nation, somewhat
prone to indifference to collegiate
reputation, there comes a striking
confirmation of all the high scholarship and intellectual attainment for
which Johns Hopkins University
has always stood. Such a confirmation is the untold action of the
Chinese Government in calling Dr.
Willoughby to China and in asking
President Goodnow to retain the
post of constitutional advisor.
The honor is paid primarily to
the men called upon to occupy these
positions, but in recognition of the
abilities of these men the Chinese
Government is also recognizing the
worth of Hopkins standards and
the reputation which this University everywhere enjoys. It is an
honor which comes but once in a
generation, and which is all the
more meaningful in that it is paid
by a nation which. is but beginning
to realize itself and which needs
counsel at this petiod more than it
ever has ill the entire course of its
history.

The most cordial relationship has
always existed between Hopkins
and the men at the head of Chinese
scholarship and progress. China
looks to this institution perhaps as

much as to any other in this country for the furtherance of that interchange of ideals which is essential to the thorough understanding
of one country by another. Th(
positions of President Goodnow
and Dr. Willoughby are significant
not only for the recognition whiclthey pay to this University's attainments, but for the promise ol
friendly and mutual developmetv
which they bear to both China anc
the United States and to the world

The latest report of the Rockefeller General Education Board
states • that the full-time plan of
Instruction inaugurated several
years ago at the Johns Hopkins
Hospital through the million-dollar fund given by the Board has,
in every way, justified the expectations which were made at its installation. This plan provides, in
brief, that the professors in the various branches of medicine, surgery and pediatrics, spend all of
their time at the hospital and
medical school, withdrawing . entirely from private practice.
The report of the Board states
that the transition from the old
arrangement to the new was made
with
any friction whatever.
Every interest concerned, it proceeds, has benefited by the change.
The younger men especially have
opportunity of working in closer
and more constant association
with the full-time • professors, • for
as they obtain their training from
the departmental heads, their opportunities to learn are vastly
greater when their head chief devotes all his time to the hospital.
The fact that no professor
working under the present arrang,ement has any outside demands has caw,.ed the weekly
meetings of. the various departments to be excellently attended,
not only by the students, but by
directors of the full-time departments and their assistants. The
men who are doing research work
in the laboratories also contribute
to the disc,ussions. Such a conference could have been before only
irregularly attended.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 27, 1916.

8

TO INVESTIGATE PRISON CAMPS MADE ADVISOR TO NEW EMPIRE
Hopkins Doctors, at Request of Great
Britain, Leave for Germany to
Make Report on State
of Prisoners.

Dr. Willoughby to Go to China to Help
Government—Pres. Goodnow, Acting
in Baltimore, to Retain Post of
Constitutional Advisor.

Two Hopkins doctors, Dr. S. V.
Irwin, '14, of Oakland, Cal., and
Dr. J. P. Webster, '13, of Plymouth, N. H., have been chosen by
the State Department to go to Germany for the purpose of inspecting
some of that country's great prison
camps. These men are now on
their way to Berlin, where they will
report to the American Red Cross
headquarters at the American Embassy.
The English Government, after
receiving many reports concerning
the harsh treatment of German
prisdners, requested the State Department of this country to name
two surgeons to visit the British
prison camps in Germany. Before
any doctors could be sent, it was
necessary to obtain permission from
the German Imperial Government
for these men to visit the camps.
The German military authorities, it
is said, however, welcomed an opportunity to have the prisons inspected by impartial observers; and
so readily granted the request.
Doctors Irwin and Webster will,
therefore, have access to all the immense prison camps, where thousands of British, French and Belgium prisoners are confined.
The Bal'imoreans will devote
most of their time to the British
camps and their reports will be
made to London. It is likely that
a report of the conduct of the
camps, the sanitary arrangements
and other details will also be made
to the American Red Cross.

Dr. W. W. Willoughby, a professor of political science at this
University, has announc,ed that
he is going to leave for China
about May 1 to act as advisor to
the Chinese Government.
Yuan Shi Kai, the ex-president
and present Emperor of China,
has renewed the agreement with
Dr. Goodnow, the president of
Johns Hopkins University, by
which Dr. Goodnow remains the
constitutional advisor of the empire. In this manner there will be
two Hopkins men aiding the newly formed empire; Dr. Willoughby in Pekin, and Dr. Goodnow in
Baltimore. There will be no special fields of governmental activity to which the men will devote
their attention, but they will give
their advice on any problems
which may be submitted to them.
Dr. Willoughby has been granted permission to go to China by
the Board of Trustees.
When his work there is finished
he will return to the University.

PROF. CHRISTIE LECTURES:- ON
ROCKY MOUNTAINS OF CANADA

An excellent lecture was given
last Monday evening in McCoy
Hall by Prof. A. G. Christie on
"The Rocky Mountains of Canada." The many magnificent pictures with which the talk was illustrated proved equally interesting.
Views were shown later of
spots such as Lake Louise, and
the Selkirks, familiar to all tourists; and of the more secluded
places visited only by the campers. There were also some remarkable views of mountain
climbing, of the Glaciers, and of
the few remaining wild animals
of the Northwest.
In the majesty of its mountains,
in the beauty of its glaciers and
lakes, the Rockies of Canada, said
the lecturer, may well be compared with the scenery of Switzerland.

The bill under which Hopkins
will have military training was outlined in the Senate Chamber on
March 18 by Senator Hardwick,
its sponsor, as follows:
"Whenever the authorities of any
school or college shall apply for
Federal aid in the establishment of
a military organization, and shall
furnish a statement that so or more
young men or boys, students at
their institution, above the age of
15 and with the consent of their
parents in the case of minors, have
declared their willingness to join,
their statement shall be investigated
by the War Department, and, if
verified, shall justify the War Department in furnishing the organization with full equipment, arms
and ammunition. The military instruction and direction shall be under an army officer detailed by the
Department to serve in that capacity.
"This reserve should not be subject to mobilization during the
school or college term in time of
peace. During the summer, however, the different organizations
could be mobilized for regimental
or brigade training and maneuvers.
During such time aS they were ocpied in the summer, they should receive pay for their services.
"The President is given the authority to call out this reserve in
time or war.
"The sum of $20,000,00o, or
whatever part of it is necessary,
is to be appropriated to carry out
the provisions of this bill."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 27, 1916.

TENNIS SCHEDULE ANNOUNCED

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG

Practice of Team Already Under Way
New Material on Hand to Fill
Up Loss of Former
Players.

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

The spring practice of the Johns
Hopkins University Tennis Team
has already begun, and with the addition of a number of new stars the
prospects of the success of the
team this year are unusually
bright.
The men who played on the team
last year are Sydney Morgan, A.
L. Hammond, the present manager; Walter Taylor, the present
captain; Erwin /Roach, Peyton
Strobel, W. R. Jacobsen, and M.
R. McLean. Of these, Morgan,
Roach and McLean have left the
University. The loss of Morgan is
especially felt, as he was a star
player, having held the championship of the University for the past
three years.
With these old men as a nucleus,
however, and with the addition of
Warren .Allen, captain of last
year's City College team; W. L.
Linton, of last year's - four of
the West Virginia team; Flowers, Medical School, of last
year's Wesleyan team; Webster, Medical School, of Amherst;
William Love, Simeon Kloskey,
Joel Gutman, F. K. Ebaugh, Michael School and others, Hopkins
has no cause to deplore the lack
of available material.
A. L. Hammond, the manager of
this year's team, has arranged an
especially strong and attractive
schedule. The first game is played
on April 15, and the last one is
scheduled on June io, soon after
the closing of the final term. The
schedule is as follows:
April 15—Gettysburg, at Gettysburg.
April 19—Navy, at Annapolis.
April 2I—Princeton, at FIomewood.
April 28—Trinity, at H o m ewood. •
May 6--Catholic University, at
Washington.
May io--Haverford, at Homewood.
May Tr—Virginia, at H o m ewood.
May I2—University of P e n nsy.lvania, at Philadelphia.
May 13—Rutgers, at New
Brunswick. .
May 19—Michigan, at H o m ewood.
May 20—Georgetown, at Washing-ton.
May 27—St. John's, at Annapolis.
June io--Washington College,
at Chestertown.

A Criticism of the Inter-fraternity Board.

THE NV's-LETTER:
Is the r916 Inter - Fraternity
Board justifying its existence? The
first Board was organized with the
primary purpose of setting up satisfactory rules to govern "rushing". This is the year 1916, and
the heir of those earlier days is still
setting up rules to govern rushing.
Surely by this time the stress of
organizing need no longer claim its
attention. And could one dare suggest that a Board chosen from the
best that the Fraternities have to
offer, either does not care enough
or has not vision enough to confront and seek as an inter-fraternity body a solution for other and
more intimate problems of fraternity life?
It is the fond desire of those who
have once served on boards or
councils to gracefully and gratefully pass the toga to others, and
then to slip out to be one of that
"silent succession" that has already
gone on. That, some consider, is
the height of wisdom. First, it
saves trouble. And then, too, none
call remark that trite but everforceful: "Why don't you mind
your own business ?"
I beg for this day to be one
apart from that "silent succession,"
and to boldly ask why fraternity
men at Hopkins, as a body, have
never considered, for instance, the
question of Fraternity Scholarship.
Lo, and we see an excited gentleman in the far corner arise and
exclaim without taking breath:(1)
"We maintain our scholarship
through committees working within the separate fraternities." (2)
"How could we improve on that?"
(3) "Anyway, that's not the InterFraternity Board's business."
The excited gentleman, of course,
demands an answer. Suppose we
say to( )that the spur to scholarship under a committee plan in the
separate fraternity is, as a rule, only
as vivid as the personality of the
chairman of the committee, and
consequently the stimulation of
scholarship will fluctuate violently
—and often, lamentably. (3) You
say that is not the business of the
Inter-Fraternity Board :- Do you

SENIORS, SOPHS AND FRESHIES
PREPARE FOR BANQUETS

The committees of all the
classes except the Junior, whose
banquet was held last Monday
night at the Rennert Hotel, are
busy planning the respective class
banquets in order that they may
be held before the Easter holidays.
The Senior Class has put its
banquet in charge of a committee
composed of McDowell, chairman; M. E. Bagley, Vickers and
Ludington. These men are planning to hold their banquet very
shortly, but no definite plans have
yet been made.
The Sophomore committee, consisting of Henry Evans, chairman; Sutton, Edgerton, Hoffman,
and Duncan, are planning a new
feature which is to be a surprise
to everyone, and which they refuse to disclose in any way. At
present the committee intends to
hold the banquet on April 4, at
the Hotel Rennert; the price
being $2.00 a plate. Alex. Wolf,
the president of the Sophomore
class, will act as toastmaster, and
a number of speeches will be made
by members of the class.
The committee in charge of the
Freshman banquet, made up of
Harris Kirk, chairman; Haskell,
Carroll, Lentz, Baxley and W.
Stokes, has been at work on the
various features of the occasion,
but has not decided definitely on
the date or the place. It is most
likely that the banquet will be
held sometime after the Sophomore banquet, ill accordance with
the Hopkins tradition. Harris E.
Kirke will act as the Freshman
toastmaster. ,The price of the
banquet will be $2.00 a plate.
know that some people choose for
their pet argument that members
of college societies stand lower in
their studies than non-members?
We think that untrue, but why not
prove that the fraternities are ambitious for scholarship? Why not
convince the skeptic instead of
fruitlessly arguing with him; and,
to devise regular, universal and effective means to uphold fraternity
scholarship, who can better take the
initiative than the Inter-Fraternity
Board? Besides, why should not
the 1916 Board be a little original?
The excited gentleman arises
again to remark: "Aha, you took
pains to skip (2)."
"I certainly çid, Sir, hoping that
before the next issue of THE NEWSLETTER you might be interested sufficiently to work out the matter to
your own satisfaction, remembering that any plan for betterment of
inter-fraternity scholarship needs
be generally agreeable, automatic,

9
and fed and sustained by praiseworthy rivalry."
They say that the next NEWSLETTER comes out in a week; meanwhile, think it over, gentlemen.
Yours,
X.
March 24, 1916.

The last speaker of the evening
was Mr. William A. Selhorst, of
Loyola College, who spoke on "A
Plea for an Over-Government:"
The instrument for such an organization, the speaker claimed, lay in
The Hague Tribunal. He then went
on to show how the first governmental group had been the family,
how, in order, had come the tribe,
the petty kingdom, and the united
kingdom. Recently, he declared,
another step had been taken in the
uniting of the chief powers of Europe and Asia into two alliances,
with the powers of this continent
practically forming a third. The
final step, he said, will be a coalition of these three alliances, and a
federation of the world.
